And if I do not by thy hand, thou art
No Seruant of thy Maſters. Againſt Selfe-ſlaughter,
There is a prohibition ſo Diuine,
That crauens my weake hand: Come, heere’s my heart:
Something’s a-foot: Soft, ſoft, wee’l no defence,
Obedient as the Scabbard. What is heere,
The Scriptures of the Loyall Leonatus,
All turn’d to Hereſie? Away, away
Corrupters of my Faith, you ſhall no more
Be Stomachers to my heart: thus may poore Fooles
Beleeue falſe Teachers: Though thoſe that are betraid
Do feele the Treaſon ſharpely, yet the Traitor
Stands in worſe caſe of wœ. And thou Poſthumus,
That didd’ſt ſet vp my diſobedience ’gainſt the King
My Father, and makes me put into contempt the ſuites
Of Princely Fellowes, ſhalt heereafter finde
It is no aƈte of common paſſage, but
A ſtraine of Rareneſſe: and I greeue my ſelfe,
To thinke, when thou ſhalt be diſedg’d by her,
That now thou tyreſt on, how thy memory
Will then be pang’d by me. Prythee diſpatch,
The Lambe entreats the Butcher. Wher’s thy knife?
Thou art too ſlow to do thy Maſters bidding
When I deſire it too.

speech.speaker: Piſ.
speech.line: Oh gracious Lady:
Since I receiu’d command to do this buſineſſe,
I haue not ſlept one winke.

speech.speaker: Imo.
speech.line: Doo’t, and to bed then.

speech.speaker: Piſ.
speech.line: Ile wake mine eye-balles firſt.

speech.speaker: Imo.
speech.line: Wherefore then
Didd’ſt vndertake it? Why haſt thou abus’d
So many Miles, with a pretence? This place?
Mine Aƈtion? and thine owne? Our Horſes labour?
The Time inuiting thee? The perturb’d Court
For my being abſent? whereunto I neuer
Purpoſe returne. Why haſt thou gone ſo farre
To be vn-bent? when thou haſt ’tane thy ſtand,
Th’eleƈted Deere before thee?

speech.speaker: Piſ.
speech.line: But to win time
To looſe ſo bad employment, in the which
I haue conſider’d of a courſe: good Ladie
Heare me with patience.

speech.speaker: Imo.
speech.line: Talke thy tongue weary, ſpeake:
I haue heard I am a Strumpet, and mine eare
Therein falſe ſtrooke, can take no greater wound,
Nor tent, to bottome that. But ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Piſ.
speech.line: Then Madam,
I thought you would not backe againe.

speech.speaker: Imo.
speech.line: Moſt like,
Bringing me heere to kill me.

speech.speaker: Piſ.
speech.line: Not ſo neither:
But if I were as wiſe, as honeſt, then
My purpoſe would proue well: it cannot be,
But that my Maſter is abus’d. Some Villaine,
I, and ſingular in his Art, hath done you both
This curſed iniurie.

speech.speaker: Imo.
speech.line: Some Roman Curtezan?

speech.speaker: Piſa.
speech.line: No, on my life:
Ile giue but notice you are dead, and ſend him
Some bloody ſigne of it. For ’tis commanded
I ſhould do ſo: you ſhall be miſt at Court,
And that will well confirme it.

speech.speaker: Imo.
speech.line: Why good Fellow,
What ſhall I do the while? Where bide? How liue?
Or in my life, what comfort, when I am
Dead to my Husband?

speech.speaker: Piſ.
speech.line: If you’l backe to’th’Court.

speech.speaker: Imo.
speech.line: No Court, no Father, nor no more adœ
With that harſh, noble, ſimple nothing:
That Clotten, whoſe Loue-suite hath bene to me
As fearefull as a Siege.

speech.speaker: Piſ.
speech.line: If not at Court,
Then not in Britaine muſt you bide.

speech.speaker: Imo.
speech.line: Where then?
Hath Britaine all the Sunne that ſhines? Day? Night?
Are they not but in Britaine? I’th’worlds Volume
Our Britaine ſeemes as of it, but not in’t:
In a great Poole, a Swannes-neſt, prythee thinke
There’s liuers out of Britaine.

speech.speaker: Piſ.
speech.line: I am moſt glad
You thinke of other place: Th’Ambaſſador,
Lucius the Romane comes to Milford-Hauen
To morrow. Now, if you could weare a minde
Darke, as your Fortune is, and but diſguiſe
That which t’appeare it ſelfe, muſt not yet be,
But by ſelfe-danger, you ſhould tread a courſe
Pretty, and full of view: yea, happily, neere
The reſidence of Poſthumus; ſo nie (at leaſt)
That though his Aƈtions were not viſible, yet
Report ſhould render him hourely to your eare,
As truely as he mooues.

speech.speaker: Imo.
speech.line: Oh for ſuch meanes,
Though perill to my modeſtie, not death on’t
I would aduenture.

speech.speaker: Piſ.
speech.line: Well then, heere’s the point:
You muſt forget to be a Woman: change
Command, into obedience. Feare, and Niceneſſe
(The Handmaides of all Women, or more truely
Woman it pretty ſelfe) into a waggiſh courage,
Ready in gybes, quicke-anſwer’d, ſawcie, and
As quarrellous as the Weazell: Nay, you muſt
Forget that rareſt Treaſure of your Cheeke,
Expoſing it (but oh the harder heart,
Alacke no remedy) to the greedy touch
Of common-kiſſing Titan: and forget
Your labourſome and dainty Trimmes, wherein
You made great Iuno angry.

speech.speaker: Imo.
speech.line: Nay be breefe?
I ſee into thy end, and am almoſt
A man already.

speech.speaker: Piſ.
speech.line: Firſt, make your ſelfe but like one,
Fore-thinking this. I haue already fit
(’Tis in my Cloake-bagge) Doublet, Hat, Hoſe, all
That anſwer to them: Would you in their ſeruing,
(And with what imitation you can borrow
From youth of ſuch a ſeaſon) ’fore Noble Lucius
Preſent your ſelfe, deſire his ſeruice: tell him
Wherein you’re happy; which will make him know,
If that his head haue eare in Muſicke, doubtleſſe
With ioy he will imbrace you: for hee’s Honourable,
And doubling that, moſt holy. Your meanes abroad:
You haue me rich, and I will neuer faile
Beginning, nor ſupplyment.

speech.speaker: Imo.
speech.line: Thou art all the comfort
The Gods will diet me with. Prythee away,
There’s more to be conſider’d: but wee’l euen
All that good time will giue vs. This attempt,
I am Souldier too, and will abide it with
A Princes Courage. Away, I prythee.

speech.speaker: Piſ.
speech.line: Well Madam, we muſt take a ſhort farewell,
Leaſt being miſt, I be ſuſpeƈted of
Your carriage from the Court. My Noble Miſtris,
Heere is a boxe, I had it from the Queene,
What’s in’t is precious: If you are ſicke at Sea,
Or Stomacke-qualm’d at Land, a Dramme of this
Will driue away diſtemper. To ſome ſhade,
And fit you to your Manhood: may the Gods
Direƈt you to the beſt.

speech.speaker: Imo
speech.line: Amen: I thanke thee.

scene.stagedir: Enter Cymbeline, Queene, Cloten, Lucius, and Lords.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: Thus farre, and ſo farewell.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Thankes, Royall Sir:
My Emperor hath wrote, I muſt from hence,
And am right ſorry, that I muſt report ye
My Maſters Enemy.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: Our Subieƈts (Sir)
Will not endure his yoake; and for our ſelfe
To ſhew leſſe Soueraignty then they, muſt needs
Appeare vn-Kinglike.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: So Sir: I deſire of you
A Conduƈt ouer Land, to Milford-Hauen.
Madam, all ioy befall your Grace, and you.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: My Lords, you are appointed for that Office:
The due of Honor, in no point omit:
So farewell Noble Lucius.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Your hand, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Clot.
speech.line: Receiue it friendly: but from this time forth
I weare it as your Enemy.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Sir, the Euent
Is yet to name the winner. Fare you well.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: Leaue not the worthy Lucius, good my Lords
Till he haue croſt the Seuern. Happines.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: He gœs hence frowning: but it honours vs
That we haue giuen him cauſe.

speech.speaker: Clot.
speech.line: ’Tis all the better,
Your valiant Britaines haue their wiſhes in it.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: Lucius hath wrote already to the Emperor
How it gœs heere. It fits vs therefore ripely
Our Chariots, and our Horſemen be in readineſſe:
The Powres that he already hath in Gallia
Will ſoone be drawne to head, from whence he moues
His warre for Britaine.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: ’Tis not ſleepy buſineſſe,
But muſt be look’d too ſpeedily, and ſtrongly.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: Our expeƈtation that it would be thus
Hath made vs forward. But my gentle Queene,
Where is our Daughter? She hath not appear’d
Before the Roman, nor to vs hath tender’d
The duty of the day. She looke vs like
A thing more made of malice, then of duty,
We haue noted it. Call her before vs, for
We haue beene too ſlight in ſufferance.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Royall Sir,
Since the exile of Poſthumus, moſt retyr’d
Hath her life bin: the Cure whereof, my Lord,
’Tis time muſt do. Beſeech your Maieſty,
Forbeare ſharpe ſpeeches to her. Shee’s a Lady
So tender of rebukes, that words are ſtroke;
And ſtrokes death to her.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: Where is ſhe Sir? How
Can her contempt be anſwer’d?

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: Pleaſe you Sir,
Her Chambers are all lock’d, and there’s no anſwer
That will be giuen to’th’lowd of noiſe, we make.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: My Lord, when laſt I went to viſit her,
She pray’d me to excuſe her keeping cloſe,
Whereto conſtrain’d by her infirmitie,
She ſhould that dutie leaue vnpaide to you
Which dayly ſhe was bound to proffer: this
She wiſh’d me to make knowne: but our great Court
Made me too blame in memory.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: Her doores lock’d?
Not ſeene of late? Grant Heauens, that which I
Feare, proue falſe.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Sonne, I ſay, follow the King.

speech.speaker: Clot.
speech.line: That man of hers, Piſanio, her old Seruant
I haue not ſeene theſe two dayes.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Go, looke after:
Piſanio, thou that ſtand’ſt ſo for Poſthumus,
He hath a Drugge of mine: I pray, his abſence
Proceed by ſwallowing that. For he beleeues
It is a thing moſt precious. But for her,
Where is ſhe gone? Haply diſpaire hath ſeiz’d her:
Or wing’d with feruour of her loue, ſhe’s flowne
To her deſir’d Poſthumus: gone ſhe is,
To death, or to diſhonor, and my end
Can make good vſe of either. Shee being downe,
I haue the placing of the Brittiſh Crowne.
How now, my Sonne?

speech.speaker: Clot.
speech.line: ’Tis certaine ſhe is fled:
Go in and cheere the King, he rages, none
Dare come about him.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: All the better: may
This night fore-ſtall him of the comming day.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: I loue, and hate her: for ſhe’s Faire and Royall,
And that ſhe hath all courtly parts more exquiſite
Then Lady, Ladies, Woman, from euery one
The beſt ſhe hath, and ſhe of all compounded
Out-ſelles them all. I loue her therefore, but
Diſdaining me, and throwing Fauours on
The low Poſthumus, ſlanders ſo her iudgement,
That what’s elſe rare, is choak’d: and in that point
I will conclude to hate her, nay indeede,
To be reueng’d vpon her. For, when Fooles ſhall—
Who is heere? What, are you packing ſirrah?
Come hither: Ah you precious Pandar, Villaine,
Where is thy Lady? In a word, or elſe
Thou art ſtraightway with the Fiends.

speech.speaker: Piſ.
speech.line: Oh, good my Lord.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Where is thy Lady? Or, by Iupiter,
I will not aske againe. Cloſe Villaine,
Ile haue this Secret from thy heart, or rip
Thy heart to finde it. Is ſhe with Poſthumus?
From whoſe ſo many waights of baſeneſſe, cannot
A dram of worth be drawne.

speech.speaker: Piſ.
speech.line: Alas, nay Lord,
How can ſhe be with him? When was ſhe miſs’d?
He is in Rome.

speech.speaker: Clot.
speech.line: Where is ſhe Sir? Come neerer:
No farther halting: ſatisfie me home,
What is become of her?

speech.speaker: Piſ.
speech.line: Oh, my all-worthy Lord.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: All-worthy Villaine,
Diſcouer where thy Miſtris is, at once,
At the next word: no more of worthy Lord:
Speake, or thy ſilence on the inſtant, is
Thy condemnation, and thy death.

speech.speaker: Piſ.
speech.line: Then Sir:
This Paper is the hiſtorie of my knowledge
Touching her flight.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Let’s ſee’t: I will purſue her
Euen to Auguſtus Throne.

speech.speaker: Piſ.
speech.line: Or this, or periſh.
She’s farre enough, and what he learnes by this,
May proue his trauell, not her danger.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Humh.

speech.speaker: Piſ.
speech.line: Ile write to my Lord ſhe’s dead: Oh Imogen,
Safe mayſt thou wander, ſafe returne agen.

speech.speaker: Clot.
speech.line: Sirra, is this Letter true?

speech.speaker: Piſ.
speech.line: Sir, as I thinke.

speech.speaker: Clot.
speech.line: It is Poſthumus hand, I know’t. Sirrah, if thou
would’ſt not be a Villain, but do me true ſeruice: vnder-
go thoſe Imployments wherin I ſhould haue cauſe to vſe
thee with a ſerious induſtry, that is, what villainy ſœre I
bid thee do to performe it, direƈtly and truely, I would
thinke thee an honeſt man: thou ſhould’ſt neither want
my meanes for thy releefe, nor my voyce for thy prefer-
ment.

speech.speaker: Piſ.
speech.line: Well, my good Lord.

speech.speaker: Clot.
speech.line: Wilt thou ſerue mee? For ſince patiently and
conſtantly thou haſt ſtucke to the bare Fortune of that
Begger Poſthumus, thou canſt not in the courſe of grati-
tude, but be a diligent follower of mine. Wilt thou ſerue
mee?

speech.speaker: Piſ.
speech.line: Sir, I will.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Giue mee thy hand, heere’s my purſe. Haſt any
of thy late Maſters Garments in thy poſſeſſion?

speech.speaker: Piſan.
speech.line: I haue (my Lord) at my Lodging, the ſame
Suite he wore, when he tooke leaue of my Ladie & Mi-
ſtreſſe.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: The firſt ſeruice thou doſt mee, fetch that Suite
hither, let it be thy firſt ſeruice, go.

speech.speaker: Piſ.
speech.line: I ſhall my Lord.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Meet thee at Milford-Hauen: (I forgot to aske
him one thing, Ile remember’t anon:) euen there, thou
villaine Poſthumus will I kill thee. I would theſe Gar-
ments were come. She ſaide vpon a time (the bitterneſſe
of it, I now belch from my heart) that ſhee held the very
Garment of Poſthumus, in more reſpeƈt, then my Noble
and naturall perſon; together with the adornement of
my Qualities. With that Suite vpon my backe wil I ra-
uiſh her: firſt kill him, and in her eyes; there ſhall ſhe ſee
my valour, which wil then be a torment to hir contempt.
He on the ground, my ſpeech of inſulment ended on his
dead bodie, and when my Luſt hath dined (which, as I
ſay, to vex her, I will execute in the Cloathes that ſhe ſo
prais’d:) to the Court Ile knock her backe, foot her home
againe. She hath deſpis’d mee reioycingly, and Ile bee
merry in my Reuenge.
Be thoſe the Garments?

speech.speaker: Piſ.
speech.line: I, my Noble Lord.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: How long is’t ſince ſhe went to Milford-Hauen?

speech.speaker: Piſ.
speech.line: She can ſcarſe be there yet.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Bring this Apparrell to my Chamber, that is
the ſecond thing that I haue commanded thee. The third
is, that thou wilt be a voluntarie Mute to my deſigne. Be
but dutious, and true preferment ſhall tender it ſelfe to
thee. My Reuenge is now at Milford, would I had wings
to follow it. Come, and be true.

speech.speaker: Piſ.
speech.line: Thou bid’ſt me to my loſſe: for true to thee,
Were to proue falſe, which I will neuer bee
To him that is moſt true. To Milford go,
And finde not her, whom thou purſueſt. Flow, flow
You Heauenly bleſſings on her: This Fooles ſpeede
Be croſt with ſlowneſſe; Labour be his meede.

speech.speaker: Imo.
speech.line: I ſee a mans life is a tedious one,
I haue tyr’d my ſelfe: and for two nights together
Haue made the ground my bed. I ſhould be ſicke,
But that my reſolution helpes me: Milford,
When from the Mountaine top, Piſanio ſhew’d thee,
Thou was’t within a kenne. Oh Ioue, I thinke
Foundations flye the wretched: ſuch I meane,
Where they ſhould be releeu’d. Two Beggers told me,
I could not miſſe my way. Will poore Folkes lye
That haue Affliƈtions on them, knowing ’tis
A puniſhment, or Triall? Yes; no wonder,
When Rich-ones ſcarſe tell true. To lapſe in Fulneſſe
Is ſorer, then to lye for Neede: and Falſhood
Is worſe in Kings, then Beggers. My deere Lord,
Thou art one o’th’falſe Ones: Now I thinke on thee,
My hunger’s gone; but euen before, I was
At point to ſinke, for Food. But what is this?
Heere is a path too’t: ’tis ſome ſauage hold:
I were beſt not call; I dare not call: yet Famine
Ere cleane it o’re-throw Nature, makes it valiant.
Plentie, and Peace breeds Cowards: Hardneſſe euer
Of Hardineſſe is Mother. Hoa? who’s heere?
If any thing that’s ciuill, ſpeake: if ſauage,
Take, or lend. Hoa? No anſwer? Then Ile enter.
Beſt draw my Sword; and if mine Enemy
But feare the Sword like me, hee’l ſcarſely looke on’t.
Such a Fœ, good Heauens.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: You Polidore haue prou’d beſt Woodman, and
Are Maſter of the Feaſt: Cadwall, and I
Will play the Cooke, and Seruant, ’tis our match:
The ſweat of induſtry would dry, and dye
But for the end it workes too. Come, our ſtomackes
Will make what’s homely, ſauoury: Wearineſſe
Can ſnore vpon the Flint, when reſtie Sloth
Findes the Downe-pillow hard. Now peace be heere,
Poore houſe, that keep’ſt thy ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: I am throughly weary.

speech.speaker: Arui.
speech.line: I am weake with toyle, yet ſtrong in appetite.

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: There is cold meat i’th’Caue, we’l brouz on that
Whil’ſt what we haue kill’d, be Cook’d.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Stay, come not in:
But that it eates our viƈtualles, I ſhould thinke
Heere were a Faiery.

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: What’s the matter, Sir?

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: By Iupiter an Angell: or if not
An earthly Paragon. Behold Diuineneſſe
No elder then a Boy.

speech.speaker: Imo.
speech.line: Good maſters harme me not:
Before I enter’d heere, I call’d, and thought
To haue begg’d, or bought, what I haue took: good troth
I haue ſtolne nought, nor would not, though I had found
Gold ſtrew’d i’th’Floore. Heere’s money for my Meate,
I would haue left it on the Boord, ſo ſoone
As I had made my Meale; and parted
With Pray’rs for the Prouider.

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: Money? Youth.

speech.speaker: Aru.
speech.line: All Gold and Siluer rather turne to durt,
As ’tis no better reckon’d, but of thoſe
Who worſhip durty Gods.

speech.speaker: Imo.
speech.line: I ſee you’re angry:
Know, if you kill me for my fault, I ſhould
Haue dyed, had I not made it.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Whether bound?

speech.speaker: Imo.
speech.line: To Milford-Hauen.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: What’s your name?

speech.speaker: Imo.
speech.line: Fidele Sir: I haue a Kinſman, who
Is bound for Italy; he embark’d at Milford,
To whom being going, almoſt ſpent with hunger,
I am falne in this offence.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Prythee (faire youth)
Thinke vs no Churles: nor meaſure our good mindes
By this rude place we liue in. Well encounter’d,
’Tis almoſt night, you ſhall haue better cheere
Ere you depart; and thankes to ſtay, and eate it:
Boyes, bid him welcome.

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: Were you a woman, youth,
I ſhould woo hard, but be your Groome in honeſty:
I bid for you, as I do buy.

speech.speaker: Arui.
speech.line: Ile make’t my Comfort
He is a man, Ile loue him as my Brother:
And ſuch a welcome as I’ld giue to him
(After long abſence) ſuch is yours. Moſt welcome:
Be ſprightly, for you fall ’mongſt Friends.

speech.speaker: Imo.
speech.line: ’Mongſt Friends?
If Brothers: would it had bin ſo, that they
Had bin my Fathers Sonnes, then had my prize
Bin leſſe, and ſo more equall ballaſting
To thee Poſthumus.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: He wrings at ſome diſtreſſe.

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: Would I could free’t.

speech.speaker: Arui.
speech.line: Or I, what ere it be,
What paine it coſt, what danger: Gods!

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Hearke Boyes.

speech.speaker: Imo.
speech.line: Great men
That had a Court no bigger then this Caue,
That did attend themſelues, and had the vertue
Which their owne Conſcience ſeal’d them: laying by
That nothing-guift of differing Multitudes
Could not out-peere theſe twaine. Pardon me Gods,
I’ld change my ſexe to be Companion with them,
Since Leonatus falſe.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: It ſhall be ſo:
Boyes wee’l go dreſſe our Hunt. Faire youth come in;
Discourſe is heauy, faſting: when we haue ſupp’d
Wee’l mannerly demand thee of thy Story,
So farre as thou wilt ſpeake it.

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: Pray draw neere.

speech.speaker: Arui.
speech.line: The Night to’th’Owle,
And Morne to th’Larke leſſe welcome.

speech.speaker: Imo.
speech.line: Thankes Sir.

speech.speaker: Arui
speech.line: I pray draw neere.

scene.stagedir: Enter two Roman Senators, and Tribunes.

speech.speaker: 1.Sen.
speech.line: This is the tenor of the Emperors Writ;
That ſince the common men are now in Aƈtion
’Gainſt the Pannonians, and Dalmatians,
And that the Legions now in Gallia, are
Full weake to vndertake our Warres againſt
The falne-off Britaines, that we do incite
The Gentry to this buſineſſe. He creates
Lucius Pro-Conſull: and to you the Tribunes
For this immediate Leuy, he commands
His abſolute Commiſſion. Long liue Cæſar.

speech.speaker: Tri.
speech.line: Is Lucius Generall of the Forces?

speech.speaker: 2.Sen.
speech.line: I.

speech.speaker: Tri.
speech.line: Remaining now in Gallia?

speech.speaker: 1.Sen.
speech.line: With thoſe Legions
Which I haue ſpoke of, whereunto your leuie
Muſt be ſuppliant: the words of your Commiſſion
Will tye you to the numbers, and the time
Of their diſpatch.

speech.speaker: Tri
speech.line: We will diſcharge our duty.

speech.speaker: Clot
speech.line: I am neere to’th’place where they ſhould meet,
if Piſanio haue mapp’d it truely. How fit his Garments
ſerue me? Why ſhould his Miſtris who was made by him
that made the Taylor, not be fit too? The rather (ſauing
reuerence of the Word) for ’tis ſaide a Womans fitneſſe
comes by fits: therein I muſt play the Workman, I dare
ſpeake it to my ſelfe, for it is not Vainglorie for a man,
and his Glaſſe, to confer in his owne Chamber; I meane,
the Lines of my body are as well drawne as his; no leſſe
young, more ſtrong, not beneath him in Fortunes, be-
yond him in the aduantage of the time, aboue him in
Birth, alike conuerſant in generall ſeruices, and more re-
markeable in ſingle oppoſitions; yet this imperſeuerant
Thing loues him in my deſpight. What Mortalitie is?
Poſthumus, thy head (which now is growing vppon thy
ſhoulders) ſhall within this houre be off, thy Miſtris in-
forced, thy Garments cut to peeces before thy face: and
all this done, ſpurne her home to her Father, who may
(happily) be a little angry for my ſo rough vſage: but my
Mother hauing power of his teſtineſſe, ſhall turne all in-
to my commendations. My Horſe is tyed vp ſafe, out
Sword, and to a ſore purpoſe: Fortune put them into my
hand: This is the very deſcription of their meeting place
and the Fellow dares not deceiue me.

scene.stagedir: Enter Belarius, Guiderius, Aruiragus, and Imogen from the Caue.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: You are not well: Remaine heere in the Caue,
Wee’l come to you after Hunting.

speech.speaker: Arui.
speech.line: Brother, ſtay heere:
Are we not Brothers?

speech.speaker: Imo.
speech.line: So man and man ſhould be,
But Clay and Clay, differs in dignitie,
Whoſe duſt is both alike. I am very ſicke,

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: Go you to Hunting, Ile abide with him.

speech.speaker: Imo.
speech.line: So ſicke I am not, yet I am not well:
But not ſo Citizen a wanton, as
To ſeeme to dye, ere ſicke: So pleaſe you, leaue me,
Sticke to your Iournall courſe: the breach of Cuſtome,
Is breach of all. I am ill, but your being by me
Cannot amend me. Society, is no comfort
To one not ſociable: I am not very ſicke,
Since I can reaſon of it: pray you truſt me heere,
Ile rob none but my ſelfe, and let me dye
Stealing ſo poorely.

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: I loue thee: I haue ſpoke it,
How much the quantity, the waight as much,
As I do loue my Father.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: What? How? how?

speech.speaker: Arui.
speech.line: If it be ſinne to ſay ſo (Sir) I yoake mee
In my good Brothers fault: I know not why
I loue this youth, and I haue heard you ſay,
Loue’s reaſon’s, without reason. The Beere at doore,
And a demand who is’t ſhall dye, I’ld ſay
My Father, not this youth.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Oh noble ſtraine!
O worthineſſe of Nature, breed of Greatneſſe!
"Cowards father Cowards, & Baſe things Syre Bace;
"Nature hath Meale, and Bran; Contempt, and Grace.
I’me not their Father, yet who this ſhould bee,
Doth myracle it ſelfe, lou’d before mee.
’Tis the ninth houre o’th’Morne.

speech.speaker: Arui.
speech.line: Brother, farewell.

speech.speaker: Imo.
speech.line: I wiſh ye ſport.

speech.speaker: Arui.
speech.line: You health. — So pleaſe you Sir.

speech.speaker: Imo.
speech.line: Theſe are kinde Creatures.
Gods, what lyes I haue heard:
Our Courtiers ſay, all’s ſauage, but at Court;
Experience, oh thou diſproou’ſt Report.
Th’emperious Seas breeds Monſters; for the Diſh,
Poore Tributary Riuers, as ſweet Fiſh:
I am ſicke ſtill, heart-sicke; Piſanio,
Ile now taſte of thy Drugge.

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: I could not ſtirre him:
He ſaid he was gentle, but vnfortunate;
Diſhoneſtly affliƈted, but yet honeſt.

speech.speaker: Arui.
speech.line: Thus did he anſwer me: yet ſaid heereafter,
I might know more.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: To’th’Field, to’th’Field:
Wee’l leaue you for this time, go in, and reſt.

speech.speaker: Arui.
speech.line: Wee’l not be long away.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Pray be not ſicke,
For you muſt be our Huſwife.

speech.speaker: Imo.
speech.line: Well, or ill,
I am bound to you.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: And ſhal’t be euer.
This youth, how ere diſtreſt, appeares he hath had
Good Anceſtors.

speech.speaker: Arui.
speech.line: How Angell-like he ſings?

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: But his neate Cookerie?

speech.speaker: Arui.
speech.line: He cut our Rootes in Charraƈters,
And ſawc’ſt our Brothes, as Iuno had bin ſicke,
And he her Dieter.

speech.speaker: Arui.
speech.line: Nobly he yoakes
A ſmiling, with a ſigh; as if the ſighe
Was that it was, for not being ſuch a Smile:
The Smile, mocking the Sigh, that it would flye
From ſo diuine a Temple, to commix
With windes, that Saylors raile at.

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: I do note,
That greefe and patience rooted in them both,
Mingle their ſpurres together.

speech.speaker: Arui.
speech.line: Grow patient,
And let the ſtinking-Elder (Greefe) vntwine
His periſhing roote, with the encreaſing Vine.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: It is great morning. Come away: Who’s there?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: I cannot finde thoſe Runnagates, that Villaine
Hath mock’d me. I am faint.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Thoſe Runnagates?
Meanes he not vs? I partly know him, ’tis
Cloten, the Sonne o’th’Queene. I feare ſome Ambuſh:
I ſaw him not theſe many yeares, and yet
I know ’tis he: We are held as Out-Lawes: Hence.

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: He is but one: you, and my Brother ſearch
What Companies are neere: pray you away,
Let me alone with him.

speech.speaker: Clot.
speech.line: Soft, what are you
That flye me thus? Some villaine-Mountainers?
I haue heard of ſuch. What Slaue art thou?

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: A thing
More ſlauiſh did I ne’re, then anſwering
A Slaue without a knocke.

speech.speaker: Clot.
speech.line: Thou art a Robber,
A Law-breaker, a Villaine: yeeld thee Theefe.

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: To who? to thee? What art thou? Haue not I
An arme as bigge as thine? A heart, as bigge:
Thy words I grant are bigger: for I weare not
My Dagger in my mouth. Say what thou art:
Why I ſhould yeeld to thee?

speech.speaker: Clot.
speech.line: Thou Villaine baſe,
Know’ſt me not by my Cloathes?

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: No, nor thy Taylor, Raſcall:
Who is thy Grandfather? He made thoſe cloathes,
Which (as it ſeemes) make thee.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Thou precious Varlet,
My Taylor made them not.

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: Hence then, and thanke
The man that gaue them thee. Thou art ſome Foole,
I am loath to beate thee.

speech.speaker: Clot.
speech.line: Thou iniurious Theefe,
Heare but my name, and tremble.

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: What’s thy name?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Cloten, thou Villaine.

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: Cloten, thou double Villaine be thy name,
I cannot tremble at it, were it Toad, or Adder, Spider,
’Twould moue me ſooner.

speech.speaker: Clot.
speech.line: To thy further feare,
Nay, to thy meere Confuſion, thou ſhalt know
I am Sonne to’th’Queene.

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: I am ſorry for’t: not ſeeming
So worthy as thy Birth.

speech.speaker: Clot.
speech.line: Art not afeard?

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: Thoſe that I reuerence, thoſe I feare: the Wiſe:
At Fooles I laugh: not feare them.

speech.speaker: Clot.
speech.line: Dye the death:
When I haue ſlaine thee with my proper hand,
Ile follow thoſe that euen now fled hence:
And on the Gates of Luds-Towne ſet your heads:
Yeeld Ruſticke Mountaineer.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: No Companie’s abroad?

speech.speaker: Arui.
speech.line: None in the world: you did miſtake him ſure.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: I cannot tell: Long is it ſince I ſaw him,
But Time hath nothing blurr’d thoſe lines of Fauour
Which then he wore: the ſnatches in his voice,
And burſt of ſpeaking were as his: I am abſolute
’Twas very Cloten.

speech.speaker: Arui.
speech.line: In this place we left them;
I wiſh my Brother make good time with him,
You ſay he is ſo fell.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Being ſcarſe made vp,
I meane to man; he had not apprehenſion
Of roaring terrors: For defeƈt of iudgement
Is oft the cauſe of Feare.
But ſee thy Brother.

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: This Cloten was a Foole, an empty purſe,
There was no money in’t: Not Hercules
Could haue knock’d out his Braines, for he had none:
Yet I not doing this, the Foole had borne
My head, as I do his.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: What haſt thou done?

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: I am perfeƈt what: cut off one Clotens head,
Sonne to the Queene (after his owne report)
Who call’d me Traitor, Mountaineer, and ſwore
With his owne ſingle hand heel’d take vs in,
Diſplace our heads, where (thanks the Gods) they grow
And ſet them on Luds-Towne.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: We are all vndone.

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: Why, worthy Father, what haue we to looſe,
But that he ſwore to take our Liues? the Law
Proteƈts not vs, then why ſhould we be tender,
To let an arrogant peece of fleſh threat vs?
Play Iudge, and Executioner, all himſelfe?
For we do feare the Law. What company
Diſcouer you abroad?

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: No ſingle ſoule
Can we ſet eye on: but in all ſafe reaſon
He muſt haue ſome Attendants. Though his Honor
Was nothing but mutation, I, and that
From one bad thing to worſe: Not Frenzie,
Not abſolute madneſſe could ſo farre haue rau’d
To bring him heere alone: although perhaps
It may be heard at Court, that ſuch as wee
Caue heere, hunt heere, are Out-lawes, and in time
May make ſome ſtronger head, the which he hearing,
(As it is like him) might breake out, and ſweare
Heel’d fetch vs in, yet is’t not probable
To come alone, either he ſo vndertaking,
Or they ſo ſuffering: then on good ground we feare,
If we do feare this Body hath a taile
More perillous then the head.

speech.speaker: Arui.
speech.line: Let Ord’nance
Come as the Gods fore-ſay it: howſœre,
My Brother hath done well.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: I had no minde
To hunt this day: The Boy Fideles ſickeneſſe
Did make my way long forth.

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: With his owne Sword,
Which he did waue againſt my throat, I haue tane
His head from him: Ile throw’t into the Creeke
Behinde our Rocke, and let it to the Sea,
And tell the Fiſhes, hee’s the Queenes Sonne, Cloten,
That’s all I reake.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: I feare ’twill be reueng’d:
Would (Polidore) thou had’ſt not done’t: though valour
Becomes thee well enough.

speech.speaker: Arui.
speech.line: Would I had done’t:
So the Reuenge alone purſu’de me: Polidore
I loue thee brotherly, but enuy much
Thou haſt robb’d me of this deed: I would Reuenges
That poſſible ſtrength might meet, wold ſeek vs through
And put vs to our anſwer.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Well, ’tis done:
Wee’l hunt no more to day, nor ſeeke for danger
Where there’s no profit. I prythee to our Rocke,
You and Fidele play the Cookes: Ile ſtay
Till haſty Polidore returne, and bring him
To dinner preſently.

speech.speaker: Arui.
speech.line: Poore ſicke Fidele.
Ile willingly to him, to gaine his colour,
Il’d let a pariſh of ſuch Clotens blood,
And praiſe my ſelfe for charity.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Oh thou Goddeſſe,
Thou diuine Nature; thou thy ſelfe thou blazon’ſt
In theſe two Princely Boyes: they are as gentle
As Zephires blowing below the Violet,
Not wagging his ſweet head; and yet, as rough
(Their Royall blood enchaf’d) as the rud’ſt winde,
That by the top doth take the Mountaine Pine,
And make him ſtoope to th’Vale. ’Tis wonder
That an inuiſible inſtinƈt ſhould frame them
To Royalty vnlearn’d, Honor vntaught,
Ciuility not ſeene from other: valour
That wildely growes in them, but yeelds a crop
As if it had beene ſow’d: yet ſtill it’s ſtrange
What Clotens being heere to vs portends,
Or what his death will bring vs.

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: Where’s my Brother?
I haue ſent Clotens Clot-pole downe the ſtreame,
In Embaſſie to his Mother; his Bodie’s hoſtage
For his returne.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: My ingenuous Inſtrument,
(Hearke Polidore) it ſounds: but what occaſion
Hath Cadwal now to giue it motion? Hearke.

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: Is he at home?

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: He went hence euen now.

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: What dœs he meane?
Since death of my deer’ſt Mother
It did not ſpeake before. All ſolemne things
Should anſwer ſolemne Accidents. The matter?
Triumphes for nothing, and lamenting Toyes,
Is iollity for Apes, and greefe for Boyes.
Is Cadwall mad?

scene.stagedir: Enter Aruiragus, with Imogen dead, bearing her in his Armes.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Looke, heere he comes,
And brings the dire occaſion in his Armes,
Of what we blame him for.

speech.speaker: Arui.
speech.line: The Bird is dead
That we haue made ſo much on. I had rather
Haue ſkipt from ſixteene yeares of Age, to ſixty:
To haue turn’d my leaping time into a Crutch,
Then haue ſeene this.

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: Oh ſweeteſt, fayreſt Lilly:
My Brother weares thee not the one halfe ſo well,
As when thou grew’ſt thy ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Oh Melancholly,
Who euer yet could ſound thy bottome? Finde
The Ooze, to ſhew what Coaſt thy ſluggiſh care
Might’ſt eaſileſt harbour in. Thou bleſſed thing,
Ioue knowes what man thou might’ſt haue made: but I,
Thou dyed’ſt a moſt rare Boy, of Melancholly.
How found you him?

speech.speaker: Arui.
speech.line: Starke, as you ſee:
Thus ſmiling, as ſome Fly had tickled ſlumber,
Not as deaths dart being laugh’d at: his right Cheeke
Repoſing on a Cuſhion.

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: Where?

speech.speaker: Arui.
speech.line: O’th’floore:
His armes thus leagu’d, I thought he ſlept, and put
My clowted Brogues from off my feete, whoſe rudeneſſe
Anſwer’d my ſteps too lowd.

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: Why, he but ſleepes:
If he be gone, hee’l make his Graue, a Bed:
With female Fayries will his Tombe be haunted,
And Wormes will not come to thee.

speech.speaker: Arui.
speech.line: With fayreſt Flowers
Whil’ſt Sommer laſts, and I liue heere, Fidele,
Ile ſweeten thy ſad graue: thou ſhalt not lacke
The Flower that’s like thy face. Pale-Primroſe, nor
The azur’d Hare-Bell, like thy Veines: no, nor
The leafe of Eglantine, whom not to ſlander,
Out-ſweetned not thy breath: the Raddocke would
With Charitable bill (Oh bill ſore ſhaming
Thoſe rich-left-heyres, that let their Fathers lye
Without a Monument) bring thee all this,
Yea, and furr’d Moſſe beſides. When Flowres are none
To winter-ground thy Coarſe—

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: Prythee haue done,
And do not play in Wench-like words with that
Which is ſo ſerious. Let vs bury him,
And not protraƈt with admiration, what
Is now due debt. To’th’graue.

speech.speaker: Arui.
speech.line: Say, where ſhall’s lay him?

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: By good Euriphile, our Mother.

speech.speaker: Arui.
speech.line: Bee’t ſo:
And let vs (Polidore) though now our voyces
Haue got the manniſh cracke, ſing him to’th’ground
As once to our Mother: vſe like note, and words,
Saue that Euriphile, muſt be Fidele.

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: Cadwall,
I cannot ſing: Ile weepe, and word it with thee;
For Notes of ſorrow, out of tune, are worſe
Then Prieſts, and Phanes that lye.

speech.speaker: Arui.
speech.line: Wee’l ſpeake it then.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Great greefes I ſee med’cine the leſſe: For Cloten
Is quite forgot. He was a Queenes Sonne, Boyes,
And though he came our Enemy, remember
He was paid for that: though meane, and mighty rotting
Together haue one duſt, yet Reuerence
(That Angell of the world) doth make diſtinƈtion
Of place ’tweene high, and low. Our Fœ was Princely,
And though you tooke his life, as being our Fœ,
Yet bury him, as a Prince.

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: Pray you fetch him hither,
Therſites body is as good as Aiax,
When neyther are aliue.

speech.speaker: Arui.
speech.line: If you’l go fetch him,
Wee’l ſay our Song the whil’ſt: Brother begin.

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: Nay Cadwall, we muſt lay his head to th’Eaſt,
My Father hath a reaſon for’t.

speech.speaker: Arui.
speech.line: ’Tis true.

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: Come on then, and remoue him.

speech.speaker: Arui.
speech.line: So, begin.

speech.speaker: Guid.
speech.line: Feare no more the heate o’th’Sun,
Nor the furious Winters rages,
Thou thy worldly task haſt don,
Home art gon, and tane thy wages.
Golden Lads, and Girles all muſt,
As Chimney-Sweepers come to duſt.

speech.speaker: Arui.
speech.line: Feare no more the frowne o’th’Great,
Thou art paſt the Tirants ſtroake,
Care no more to cloath and eate,
To thee the Reede is as the Oake:
The Scepter, Learning, Phyſicke muſt,
All follow this and come to duſt.

speech.speaker: Guid.
speech.line: Feare no more the Lightning flaſh.

speech.speaker: Arui.
speech.line: Nor th’all-dreaded Thunderſtone.

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: Feare not Slander, Cenſure raſh.

speech.speaker: Arui.
speech.line: Thou haſt finiſh’d Ioy and mone.

speech.speaker: Both.
speech.line: All Louers young, all Louers muſt,
Conſigne to thee and come to duſt.

speech.speaker: Guid.
speech.line: No Exorciſor harme thee,

speech.speaker: Arui.
speech.line: Nor no witch-craft charme thee.

speech.speaker: Guid.
speech.line: Ghoſt vnlaid forbeare thee.

speech.speaker: Arui.
speech.line: Nothing ill come neere thee.

speech.speaker: Both.
speech.line: Quiet conſumation haue,
And renowned be thy graue.

scene.stagedir: Enter Belarius with the body of Cloten.

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: We haue done our obſequies:
Come lay him downe.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Heere’s a few Flowres, but ’bout midnight more:
The hearbes that haue on them cold dew o’th’night
Are ſtrewings fit’ſt for Graues: vpon their Faces.
You were as Flowres, now wither’d: euen ſo
Theſe Herbelets ſhall, which we vpon you ſtrew.
Come on, away, apart vpon our knees:
The ground that gaue them firſt, ha’s them againe:
Their pleaſures here are paſt, ſo are their paine.
Yes Sir, to Milford-Hauen, which is the way?
I thanke you: by yond buſh? pray how farre thether?
’Ods pittikins: can it be ſixe mile yet?
I haue gone all night: ’Faith, Ile lye downe, and ſleepe.
But ſoft; no Bedfellow? Oh Gods, and Goddeſſes!
Theſe Flowres are like the pleaſures of the World;
This bloody man the care on’t. I hope I dreame:
For ſo I thought I was a Caue-keeper,
And Cooke to honeſt Creatures. But ’tis not ſo:
’Twas but a bolt of nothing, ſhot of nothing,
Which the Braine makes of Fumes. Our very eyes,
Are ſometimes like our Iudgements, blinde. Good faith
I tremble ſtill with feare: but if there be
Yet left in Heauen, as ſmall a drop of pittie
As a Wrens eye; fear’d Gods, a part of it.
The Dreame’s heere ſtill: euen when I wake it is
Without me, as within me: not imagin’d, felt.
A headleſſe man? The Garments of Poſthumus?
I know the ſhape of’s Legge: this is his Hand:
His Foote Mercuriall: his martiall Thigh
The brawnes of Hercules: but his Iouiall face—
Murther in heauen? How? ’tis gone. Piſanio,
All Curſes madded Hecuba gaue the Greekes,
And mine to boot, be darted on thee: thou
Conſpir’d with that Irregulous diuell Cloten,
Hath heere cut off my Lord. To write, and read,
Be henceforth treacherous. Damn’d Piſanio,
Hath with his forged Letters (damn’d Piſanio)
From this moſt braueſt veſſell of the world
Strooke the maine top! Oh Poſthumus, alas,
Where is thy head? where’s that? Aye me! where’s that?
Piſanio might haue kill’d thee at the heart,
And left this head on. How ſhould this be, Piſanio?
’Tis he, and Cloten: Malice, and Lucre in them
Haue laid this Wœ heere. Oh ’tis pregnant, pregnant!
The Drugge he gaue me, which hee ſaid was precious
And Cordiall to me, haue I not found it
Murd’rous to’th’Senſes? That confirmes it home:
This is Piſanio’s deede, and Cloten: Oh!
Giue colour to my pale cheeke with thy blood,
That we the horrider may ſeeme to thoſe
Which chance to finde vs. Oh, my Lord! my Lord!

scene.stagedir: Enter Lucius, Captaines, and a Soothſayer.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: To them, the Legions garriſon’d in Gallia
After your will, haue croſt the Sea, attending
You heere at Milford-Hauen, with your Shippes:
They are heere in readineſſe.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: But what from Rome?

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: The Senate hath ſtirr’d vp the Confiners,
And Gentlemen of Italy, moſt willing Spirits,
That promiſe Noble Seruice: and they come
Vnder the Conduƈt of bold Iachimo,
Syenna’s Brother.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: When expeƈt you them?

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: With the next benefit o’th’winde.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: This forwardneſſe
Makes our hopes faire. Command our preſent numbers
Be muſter’d: bid the Captaines looke too’t. Now Sir,
What haue you dream’d of late of this warres purpoſe.

speech.speaker: Sooth.
speech.line: Laſt night, the very Gods ſhew’d me a viſion
(I faſt, and pray’d for their Intelligence) thus:
I ſaw Ioues Bird, the Roman Eagle wing’d
From the ſpungy South, to this part of the Weſt,
There vaniſh’d in the Sun-beames, which portends
(Vnleſſe my ſinnes abuſe my Diuination)
Succeſſe to th’Roman hoaſt.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Dreame often ſo,
And neuer falſe. Soft hoa, what truncke is heere?
Without his top? The ruine ſpeakes, that ſometime
It was a worthy building. How? a Page?
Or dead, or ſleeping on him? But dead rather:
For Nature doth abhorre to make his bed
With the defunƈt, or ſleepe vpon the dead.
Let’s ſee the Boyes face.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: Hee’s aliue my Lord.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Hee’l then inſtruƈt vs of this body: Young one,
Informe vs of thy Fortunes, for it ſeemes
They craue to be demanded: who is this
Thou mak’ſt thy bloody Pillow? Or who was he
That (otherwiſe then noble Nature did)
Hath alter’d that good Piƈture? What’s thy intereſt
In this ſad wracke? How came’t? Who is’t?
What art thou?

speech.speaker: Imo.
speech.line: I am nothing; or if not,
Nothing to be were better: This was my Maſter,
A very valiant Britaine, and a good,
That heere by Mountaineers lyes ſlaine: Alas,
There is no more ſuch Maſters: I may wander
From Eaſt to Occident, cry out for Seruice,
Try many, all good: ſerue truly: neuer
Finde ſuch another Maſter.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: ’Lacke, good youth:
Thou mou’ſt no leſſe with thy complaining, then
Thy Maiſter in bleeding: ſay his name, good Friend.

speech.speaker: Imo.
speech.line: Richard du Champ: If I do lye, and do
No harme by it, though the Gods heare, I hope
They’l pardon it. Say you Sir?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Thy name?

speech.speaker: Imo.
speech.line: Fidele Sir.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Thou doo’ſt approue thy ſelfe the very ſame:
Thy Name well fits thy Faith; thy Faith, thy Name:
Wilt take thy chance with me? I will not ſay
Thou ſhalt be ſo well maſter’d, but be ſure
No leſſe belou’d. The Romane Emperors Letters
Sent by a Conſull to me, ſhould not ſooner
Then thine owne worth preferre thee: Go with me.

speech.speaker: Imo.
speech.line: Ile follow Sir. But firſt, and’t pleaſe the Gods,
Ile hide my Maſter from the Flies, as deepe
As theſe poore Pickaxes can digge: and when
With wild wood-leaues & weeds, I ha’ ſtrew’d his graue
And on it ſaid a Century of prayers
(Such as I can) twice o’re, Ile weepe, and ſighe,
And leauing ſo his ſeruice, follow you,
So pleaſe you entertaine mee.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: I good youth,
And rather Father thee, then Maſter thee: My Friends,
The Boy hath taught vs manly duties: Let vs
Finde out the prettieſt Dazied-Plot we can,
And make him with our Pikes and Partizans
A Graue: Come, Arme him: Boy hee’s preferr’d
By thee, to vs, and he ſhall be interr’d
As Souldiers can. Be cheerefull; wipe thine eyes,
Some Falles are meanes the happier to ariſe.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: Againe: and bring me word how ’tis with her,
A Feauour with the abſence of her Sonne;
A madneſſe, of which her life’s in danger: Heauens,
How deeply you at once do touch me. Imogen,
The great part of my comfort, gone: My Queene
Vpon a deſperate bed, and in a time
When fearefull Warres point at me: Her Sonne gone,
So needfull for this preſent? It ſtrikes me, paſt
The hope of comfort. But for thee, Fellow,
Who needs muſt know of her departure, and
Doſt ſeeme ſo ignorant, wee’l enforce it from thee
By a ſharpe Torture.

speech.speaker: Piſ.
speech.line: Sir, my life is yours,
I humbly ſet it at your will: But for my Miſtris,
I nothing know where ſhe remaines: why gone,
Nor when ſhe purpoſes returne. Beſeech your Highnes,
Hold me your loyall Seruant.

speech.speaker: Lord.
speech.line: Good my Liege,
The day that ſhe was miſſing, he was heere;
I dare be bound hee’s true, and ſhall performe
All parts of his ſubieƈtion loyally. For Cloten,
There wants no diligence in ſeeking him,
And will no doubt be found.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: The time is troubleſome:
Wee’l ſlip you for a ſeaſon, but our iealouſie
Do’s yet depend.

speech.speaker: Lord.
speech.line: So pleaſe your Maieſty,
The Romaine Legions, all from Gallia drawne,
Are landed on your Coaſt, with a ſupply
Of Romaine Gentlemen, by the Senate ſent.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: Now for the Counſaile of my Son and Queen,
I am amaz’d with matter.

speech.speaker: Lord.
speech.line: Good my Liege,
Your preparation can affront no leſſe
Then what you heare of. Come more, for more you’re ready:
The want is, but to put thoſe Powres in motion,
That long to moue.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: I thanke you: let’s withdraw
And meete the Time, as it ſeekes vs. We feare not
What can from Italy annoy vs, but
We greeue at chances heere. Away.

speech.speaker: Piſa.
speech.line: I heard no Letter from my Maſter, ſince
I wrote him Imogen was ſlaine. ’Tis ſtrange:
Nor heare I from my Miſtris, who did promiſe
To yeeld me often tydings. Neither know I
What is betide to Cloten, but remaine
Perplext in all. The Heauens ſtill muſt worke:
Wherein I am falſe, I am honeſt: not true, to be true.
Theſe preſent warres ſhall finde I loue my Country,
Euen to the note o’th’King, or Ile fall in them:
All other doubts, by time let them be cleer’d,
Fortune brings in ſome Boats, that are not ſteer’d.

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: The noyſe is round about vs.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Let vs from it.

speech.speaker: Arui.
speech.line: What pleaſure Sir, we finde in life, to locke it
From Aƈtion, and Aduenture.

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: Nay, what hope
Haue we in hiding vs? This way the Romaines
Muſt, or for Britaines ſlay vs, or receiue vs
For barbarous and vnnaturall Reuolts
During their vſe, and ſlay vs after.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Sonnes,
Wee’l higher to the Mountaines, there ſecure vs.
To the Kings party there’s no going: newneſſe
Of Clotens death (we being not knowne, nor muſter’d
Among the Bands) may driue vs to a render
Where we haue liu’d; and ſo extort from’s that
Which we haue done, whoſe anſwer would be death
Drawne on with Torture.

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: This is (Sir) a doubt
In ſuch a time, nothing becomming you,
Nor ſatisfying vs.

speech.speaker: Arui.
speech.line: It is not likely,
That when they heare their Roman horſes neigh,
Behold their quarter’d Fires; haue both their eyes
And eares ſo cloyd importantly as now,
That they will waſte their time vpon our note,
To know from whence we are.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Oh, I am knowne
Of many in the Army: Many yeeres
(Though Cloten then but young) you ſee, not wore him
From my remembrance. And beſides, the King
Hath not deſeru’d my Seruice, nor your Loues,
Who finde in my Exile, the want of Breeding;
The certainty of this heard life, aye hopeleſſe
To haue the courteſie your Cradle promis’d,
But to be ſtill hot Summers Tanlings, and
The ſhrinking Slaues of Winter.

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: Then be ſo,
Better to ceaſe to be. Pray Sir, to’th’Army:
I, and my Brother are not knowne; your ſelfe
So out of thought, and thereto ſo ore-growne,
Cannot be queſtion’d.

speech.speaker: Arui.
speech.line: By this Sunne that ſhines
Ile thither: What thing is’t, that I neuer
Did ſee man dye, ſcarſe euer look’d on blood,
But that of Coward Hares, hot Goats, and Veniſon?
Neuer beſtrid a Horſe ſaue one, that had
A Rider like my ſelfe, who ne’re wore Rowell,
Nor Iron on his heele? I am aſham’d
To looke vpon the holy Sunne, to haue
The benefit of his bleſt Beames, remaining
So long a poore vnknowne.

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: By heauens Ile go,
If you will bleſſe me Sir, and giue me leaue,
Ile take the better care: but if you will not,
The hazard therefore due fall on me, by
The hands of Romaines.

speech.speaker: Arui.
speech.line: So ſay I, Amen.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: No reaſon I (since of your liues you ſet
So ſlight a valewation) ſhould reſerue
My crack’d one to more care. Haue with you Boyes:
If in your Country warres you chance to dye,
That is my Bed too (Lads) and there Ile lye.
Lead, lead; the time ſeems long, their blood thinks ſcorn
Till it flye out, and ſhew them Princes borne.

speech.speaker: Poſt.
speech.line: Yea bloody cloth, Ile keep thee: for I am wiſht
Thou ſhould’ſt be colour’d thus. You married ones,
If each of you ſhould take this courſe, how many
Muſt murther Wiues much better then themſelues
For wrying but a little? Oh Piſanio,
Euery good Seruant do’s not all Commands:
No Bond, but to do iuſt ones. Gods, if you
Should haue ’tane vengeance on my faults, I neuer
Had liu’d to put on this: ſo had you ſaued
The noble Imogen, to repent, and ſtrooke
Me (wretch) more worth your Vengeance. But alacke,
You ſnatch ſome hence for little faults; that’s loue
To haue them fall no more: you ſome permit
To ſecond illes with illes, each elder worſe,
And make them dread it, to the doœrs thrift.
But Imogen is your owne, do your beſt willes,
And make me bleſt to obey. I am brought hither
Among th’Italian Gentry, and to fight
Againſt my Ladies Kingdome: ’Tis enough
That (Britaine) I haue kill’d thy Miſtris: Peace,
Ile giue no wound to thee: therefore good Heauens,
Heare patiently my purpoſe. Ile diſrobe me
Of theſe Italian weedes, and ſuite my ſelfe
As do’s a Britaine Pezant: ſo Ile fight
Againſt the part I come with: ſo Ile dye
For thee (O Imogen) euen for whom my life
Is euery breath, a death: and thus, vnknowne,
Pittied, nor hated, to the face of perill
My ſelfe Ile dedicate. Let me make men know
More valour in me, then my habits ſhow.
Gods, put the ſtrength o’th’Leonati in me:
To ſhame the guize o’th’world, I will begin,
The fashion leſſe without, and more within.

scene.stagedir: Enter Lucius, Iachimo, and the Romane Army at one doore: and the Britaine Army at another: Leonatus Poſthumus following like a poore Souldier. They march ouer, and gœ out. Then enter againe in Skirmiſh Iachimo and Poſthumus: he vanquiſheth and diſarmeth Iachimo, and then leaues him.

speech.speaker: Iac.
speech.line: The heauineſſe and guilt within my boſome,
Takes off my manhood: I haue belyed a Lady,
The Princeſſe of this Country; and the ayre on’t
Reuengingly enfeebles me, or could this Carle,
A very drudge of Natures, haue ſubdu’de me
In my profeſſion? Knighthoods, and Honors borne
As I weare mine) are titles but of ſcorne.
If that thy Gentry (Britaine) go before
This Lowt, as he exceeds our Lords, the oddes
Is, that we ſcarſe are men, and you are Goddes.

scene.stagedir: The Battaile continues, the Britaines fly, Cymbeline is taken: Then enter to his reſcue, Bellarius, Guiderius, and Aruiragus.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Stand, ſtand, we haue th’aduantage of the ground,
The Lane is guarded: Nothing rowts vs, but
The villany of our feares.

speech.speaker: Gui. Arui.
speech.line: Stand, ſtand, and fight.

scene.stagedir: Enter Poſthumus, and ſeconds the Britaines. They Reſcue Cymbeline, and Exeunt.
Then enter Lucius, Iachimo, and Imogen.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Away boy from the Troopes, and ſaue thy ſelfe:
For friends kil friends, and the diſorder’s ſuch
As warre were hood-wink’d.

speech.speaker: Iac.
speech.line: ’Tis their freſh ſupplies.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: It is a day turn’d ſtrangely: or betimes
Let’s re-inforce, or fly.

scene.stagedir: Enter Poſthumus, and a Britaine Lord.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Cam’ſt thou from where they made the ſtand?

speech.speaker: Poſt.
speech.line: I did,
Though you it ſeemes come from the Fliers?

speech.speaker: Lo.
speech.line: I did.

speech.speaker: Poſt.
speech.line: No blame be to you Sir, for all was loſt,
But that the Heauens fought: the King himſelfe
Of his wings deſtitute, the Army broken,
And but the backes of Britaines ſeene; all flying
Through a ſtrait Lane, the Enemy full-heart’d,
Lolling the Tongue with ſlaught’ring: hauing worke
More plentifull, then Tooles to doo’t: ſtrooke downe
Some mortally, ſome ſlightly touch’d, ſome falling
Meerely through feare, that the ſtrait paſſe was damm’d
With deadmen, hurt behinde, and Cowards liuing
To dye with length’ned ſhame.

speech.speaker: Lo.
speech.line: Where was this Lane?

speech.speaker: Poſt.
speech.line: Cloſe by the battell, ditch’d, & wall’d with turph,
Which gaue aduantage to an ancient Soldiour
(An honeſt one I warrant) who deſeru’d
So long a breeding, as his white beard came to,
In doing this for’s Country. Athwart the Lane,
He, with two ſtriplings (Lads more like to run
The Country baſe, then to commit ſuch ſlaughter,
With faces fit for Maskes, or rather fayrer
Then thoſe for preſeruation cas’d, or ſhame)
Made good the paſſage, cryed to thoſe that fled.
Our Britaines hearts dye flying, not our men,
To darkneſſe fleete ſoules that flye backwards; ſtand,
Or we are Romanes, and will giue you that
Like beaſts, which you ſhun beaſtly, and may ſaue
But to looke backe in frowne: Stand, ſtand. Theſe three,
Three thouſand confident, in aƈte as many:
For three performers are the File, when all
The reſt do nothing. With this word ſtand, ſtand,
Accomodated by the Place; more Charming
With their owne Nobleneſſe, which could haue turn’d
A Diſtaffe, to a Lance, guilded pale lookes;
Part ſhame, part ſpirit renew’d, that ſome turn’d coward
But by example (Oh a ſinne in Warre,
Damn’d in the firſt beginners) gan to looke
The way that they did, and to grin like Lyons
Vpon the Pikes o’th’Hunters. Then beganne
A ſtop i’th’Chaſer; a Retyre: Anon
A Rowt, confuſion thicke: forthwith they flye
Chickens, the way which they ſtopt Eagles: Slaues
The ſtrides the Viƈtors made: and now our Cowards
Like Fragments in hard Voyages became
The life o’th’need: hauing found the backe doore open
Of the vnguarded hearts: heauens, how they wound,
Some ſlaine before ſome dying; ſome their Friends
Ore-borne i’th’former waue, ten chac’d by one,
Are now each one the ſlaughter-man of twenty:
Thoſe that would dye, or ere reſiſt, are growne
The mortall bugs o’th’Field.

speech.speaker: Lord.
speech.line: This was ſtrange chance:
A narrow Lane, an old man, and two Boyes.

speech.speaker: Poſt.
speech.line: Nay, do not wonder at it: you are made
Rather to wonder at the things you heare,
Then to worke any. Will you Rime vpon’t,
And vent it for a Mock’rie? Heere is one:
"Two Boyes, an Oldman (twice a Boy) a Lane,
"Preſeru’d the Britaines, was the Romanes bane.

speech.speaker: Lord.
speech.line: Nay, be not angry Sir.

speech.speaker: Poſt.
speech.line: Lacke, to what end?
Who dares not ſtand his Fœ, Ile be his Friend:
For if hee’l do, as he is made to doo,
I know hee’l quickly flye my friendſhip too.
You haue put me into Rime.

speech.speaker: Lord
speech.line: Farewell, you’re angry.

speech.speaker: Poſt.
speech.line: Still going? This is a Lord: Oh Noble miſery
To be i’th’Field, and aske what newes of me:
To day, how many would haue giuen their Honours
To haue ſau’d their Carkaſſes? Tooke heele to doo’t,
And yet dyed too. I, in mine owne wœ charm’d
Could not finde death, where I did heare him groane,
Nor feele him where he ſtrooke. Being an vgly Monſter,
’Tis ſtrange he hides him in freſh Cups, ſoft Beds,
Sweet words; or hath mœ miniſters then we
That draw his kniues i’th’War. Well I will finde him:
For being now a Fauourer to the Britaine,
No more a Britaine, I haue reſum’d againe
The part I came in. Fight I will no more,
But yeeld me to the verieſt Hinde, that ſhall
Once touch my ſhoulder. Great the ſlaughter is
Heere made by’th’Romane; great the Anſwer be
Britaines muſt take. For me, my Ranſome’s death,
On eyther ſide I come to ſpend my breath;
Which neyther heere Ile keepe, nor beare agen,
But end it by ſome meanes for Imogen.
Great Iupiter be prais’d, Lucius is taken,
’Tis thought the old man, and his ſonnes, were Angels.
There was a fourth man, in a ſilly habit,
That gaue th’Affront with them.
So ’tis reported:
But none of ’em can be found. Stand, who’s there?

speech.speaker: Poſt.
speech.line: A Roman,
Who had not now beene drooping heere, if Seconds
Had anſwer’d him.
Lay hands on him: a Dogge,
A legge of Rome ſhall not returne to tell
What Crows haue peckt them here: he brags his ſeruice
As if he were of note: bring him to’th’King.

scene.stagedir: Enter Cymbeline, Belarius, Guiderius, Aruiragus, Piſanio, and Romane Captiues. The Captaines preſent Poſthumus to Cymbeline, who deliuers him ouer to a Gaoler.

speech.speaker: Gao.
speech.line: You ſhall not now be ſtolne,
You haue lockes vpon you:
So graze, as you finde Paſture.

speech.speaker: 2.Gao.
speech.line: I, or a ſtomacke.

speech.speaker: Poſt.
speech.line: Moſt welcome bondage; for thou art a way
(I thinke) to liberty: yet am I better
Then one that’s ſicke o’th’Gowt, ſince he had rather
Groane ſo in perpetuity, then be cur’d
By’th’ſure Phyſitian, Death; who is the key
T’vnbarre theſe Lockes. My Conſcience, thou art fetter’d
More then my ſhanks, & wriſts: you good Gods giue me
The penitent Inſtrument to picke that Bolt,
Then free for euer. Is’t enough I am ſorry?
So Children temporall Fathers do appeaſe;
Gods are more full of mercy. Muſt I repent,
I cannot do it better then in Gyues,
Deſir’d, more then conſtrain’d, to ſatisfie
If of my Freedome ’tis the maine part, take
No ſtriƈter render of me, then my All.
I know you are more clement then vilde men,
Who of their broken Debtors take a third,
A ſixt, a tenth, letting them thriue againe
On their abatement; that’s not my deſire.
For Imogens deere life, take mine, and though
’Tis not ſo deere, yet ’tis a life; you coyn’d it,
’Tweene man, and man, they waigh not euery ſtampe:
Though light, take Peeces for the figures ſake,
(You rather) mine being yours: and ſo great Powres,
If you will take this Audit, take this life,
And cancell theſe cold Bonds. Oh Imogen,
Ile ſpeake to thee in ſilence.

scene.stagedir: Solemne Muſicke. Enter (as in an Apparation) Sicillius Leonatus, Father to Poſthumus, an old man, attyred like a warriour, leading in his hand an ancient Matron (his wife, & Mother to Poſthumus) with Muſicke before them. Then after other Muſicke, followes the two young Leonati (Brothers to Poſthumus) with wounds as they died in the warrs. They circle Poſthumus round as he lies ſleeping.

speech.speaker: Sicil.
speech.line: No more thou Thunder-Maſter
ſhew thy ſpight, on Mortall Flies:
With Mars fall out with Iuno chide, that thy Adulteries
Rates, and Reuenges.
Hath my poore Boy done ought but well,
whoſe face I neuer ſaw:
I dy’de whil’ſt in the Wombe he ſtaide,
attending Natures Law.
Whoſe Father then (as men report,
thou Orphanes Father art)
Thou ſhould’ſt haue bin, and ſheelded him,
from this earth-vexing ſmart.

scene.speech: Moth. Lucina lent not me her ayde, but tooke me in my Throwes, That from me was Poſthumus ript, came crying ’mong’ſt his Fœs. A thing of pitty.

speech.speaker: Sicil.
speech.line: Great Nature like his Anceſtrie,
moulded the ſtuffe ſo faire:
That he deſeru’d the praiſe o’th’World,
as great Sicilius heyre.

speech.speaker: 1.Bro.
speech.line: When once he was mature for man,
in Britaine where was hee
That could ſtand vp his paralell?
Or fruitfull obieƈt bee?
In eye of Imogen, that beſt could deeme
his dignitie.

speech.speaker: Mo.
speech.line: With Marriage wherefore was he mockt
to be exil’d, and throwne
From Leonati Seate, and caſt from her,
his deereſt one:
Sweete Imogen?

speech.speaker: Sic.
speech.line: Why did you ſuffer Iachimo, ſlight thing of Italy,
To taint his Nobler hart & braine, with needleſſe ielouſy,
And to become the geeke and ſcorne o’th’others vilany?

speech.speaker: 2 Bro.
speech.line: For this, from ſtiller Seats we came,
our Parents, and vs twaine,
That ſtriking in our Countries cauſe,
fell brauely, and were ſlaine,
Our Fealty, & Tenantius right, with Honor to maintaine.

speech.speaker: 1 Bro.
speech.line: Like hardiment Poſthumus hath
to Cymbeline perform’d:
Then Iupiter, ӳ King of Gods, why haſt ӳ thus adiourn’d
The Graces for his Merits due, being all to dolors turn’d?

speech.speaker: Sicil.
speech.line: Thy Chriſtall window ope; looke,
looke out, no longer exerciſe
Vpon a valiant Race, thy harſh, and potent iniuries:

speech.speaker: Moth.
speech.line: Since (Iupiter) our Son is good,
take off his miſeries.

speech.speaker: Sicil.
speech.line: Peepe through thy Marble Manſion, helpe,
or we poore Ghoſts will cry
To’th’ſhining Synod of the reſt, againſt thy Deity.

speech.speaker: Brothers.
speech.line: Helpe (Iupiter) or we appeale,
and from thy iuſtice flye.

scene.stagedir: Iupiter deſcends in Thunder and Lightning, ſitting vppon an Eagle: hee throwes a Thunder-bolt. The Ghoſtes fall on their knees.

speech.speaker: Iupiter.
speech.line: No more you petty Spirits of Region low
Offend our hearing: huſh. How dare you Ghoſtes
Accuſe the Thunderer, whoſe Bolt (you know)
Sky-planted, batters all rebelling Coaſts.
Poore ſhadowes of Elizium, hence, and reſt
Vpon your neuer-withering bankes of Flowres.
Be not with mortall accidents oppreſt,
No care of yours it is, you know ’tis ours.
Whom beſt I loue, I croſſe; to make my guift
The more delay’d, delighted. Be content,
Your low-laide Sonne, our Godhead will vplift:
His Comforts thriue, his Trials well are ſpent:
Our Iouiall Starre reign’d at his Birth, and in
Our Temple was he married: Riſe, and fade,
He ſhall be Lord of Lady Imogen,
And happier much by his Affliƈtion made
This Tablet lay vpon his Breſt, wherein
Our pleaſure, his full Fortune, doth confine,
And ſo away: no farther with your dinne
Expreſſe Impatience, leaſt you ſtirre vp mine:
Mount Eagle, to my Palace Chriſtalline.

speech.speaker: Sicil.
speech.line: He came in Thunder, his Celeſtiall breath
Was ſulphurous to ſmell: the holy Eagle
Stoop’d, as to foote vs: his Aſcenſion is
More ſweet then our bleſt Fields: his Royall Bird
Prunes the immortall wing, and cloyes his Beake,
As when his God is pleas’d.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: Thankes Iupiter.

speech.speaker: Sic.
speech.line: The Marble Pauement clozes, he is enter’d
His radiant Roofe: Away, and to be bleſt
Let vs with care performe his great beheſt.

speech.speaker: Poſt.
speech.line: Sleepe, thou haſt bin a Grandſire, and begot
A Father to me: and thou haſt created
A Mother, and two Brothers. But (oh ſcorne)
Gone, they went hence ſo ſoone as they were borne:
And ſo I am awake. Poore Wretches, that depend
On Greatneſſe, Fauour; Dreame as I haue done,
Wake, and finde nothing. But (alas) I ſwerue:
Many Dreame not to finde, neither deſerue,
And yet are ſteep’d in Fauours; ſo am I
That haue this Golden chance, and know not why:
What Fayeries haunt this ground? A Book? Oh rare one,
Be not, as is our fangled world, a Garment
Nobler then that it couers. Let thy effeƈts
So follow, to be moſt vnlike our Courtiers,
As good, as promiſe.

line.italic: When as a Lyons whelpe, ſhall to himſelfe vnknown, with-
out ſeeking finde, and bee embrac’d by a peece of tender
Ayre: And when from a ſtately Cedar ſhall be lopt branches,
which being dead many yeares, ſhall after reuiue, bee ioynted to
the old Stocke, and freſhly grow, then ſhall Poſthumus end his
miſeries, Britaine be fortunate, and flouriſh in Peace and Plen-
tie.

speech.line: ’Tis ſtill a Dreame: or elſe ſuch ſtuffe as Madmen
Tongue, and braine not: either both, or nothing
Or ſenſeleſſe ſpeaking, or a ſpeaking ſuch
As ſenſe cannot vntye. Be what it is,
The Aƈtion of my life is like it, which Ile keepe
If but for ſimpathy.

speech.speaker: Gao.
speech.line: Come Sir, are you ready for death?

speech.speaker: Poſt.
speech.line: Ouer-roaſted rather: ready long ago.

speech.speaker: Gao.
speech.line: Hanging is the word, Sir, if you bee readie for
that, you are well Cook’d.

speech.speaker: Poſt.
speech.line: So if I proue a good repaſt to the Speƈtators, the
diſh payes the ſhot.

speech.speaker: Gao.
speech.line: A heauy reckoning for you Sir: But the comfort
is you ſhall be called to no more payments, fear no more
Tauerne Bils, which are often the ſadneſſe of parting, as
the procuring of mirth: you come in faint for want of
meate, depart reeling with too much drinke: ſorrie that
you haue payed too much, and ſorry that you are payed
too much: Purſe and Braine, both empty: the Brain the
heauier, for being too light; the Purſe too light, being
drawne of heauineſſe. Oh, of this contradiƈtion you ſhall
now be quit: Oh the charity of a penny Cord, it ſummes
vp thouſands in a trice: you haue no true Debitor, and
Creditor but it: of what’s paſt, is, and to come, the diſ-
charge: your necke (Sir) is Pen, Booke, and Counters; ſo
the Acquittance followes.

speech.speaker: Poſt.
speech.line: I am merrier to dye, then thou art to liue.

speech.speaker: Gao.
speech.line: Indeed Sir, he that ſleepes, feeles not the Tooth-
Ache: but a man that were to ſleepe your ſleepe, and a
Hangman to helpe him to bed, I think he would change
places with his Officer: for, look you Sir, you know not
which way you ſhall go.

speech.speaker: Poſt.
speech.line: Yes indeed do I, fellow.

speech.speaker: Gao.
speech.line: Your death has eyes in’s head then: I haue not
ſeene him ſo piƈtur’d: you muſt either bee direƈted by
ſome that take vpon them to know, or to take vpon your
ſelfe that which I am ſure you do not know: or iump the
after-enquiry on your owne perill: and how you ſhall
ſpeed in your iournies end, I thinke you’l neuer returne
to tell one.

speech.speaker: Poſt.
speech.line: I tell thee, Fellow, there are none want eyes, to
direƈt them the way I am going, but ſuch as winke, and
will not vſe them.

speech.speaker: Gao.
speech.line: What an infinite mocke is this, that a man ſhold
haue the beſt vſe of eyes, to ſee the way of blindneſſe: I
am ſure hanging’s the way of winking.

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: Knocke off his Manacles, bring your Priſoner to
the King.

speech.speaker: Poſt.
speech.line: Thou bring’ſt good newes, I am call’d to bee
made free.

speech.speaker: Gao.
speech.line: Ile be hang’d then.

speech.speaker: Poſt.
speech.line: Thou ſhalt be then freer then a Gaoler; no bolts
for the dead.

speech.speaker: Gao.
speech.line: Vnleſſe a man would marry a Gallowes, & be-
get yong Gibbets, I neuer ſaw one ſo prone: yet on my
Conſcience, there are verier Knaues deſire to liue, for all
he be a Roman; and there be ſome of them too that dye
againſt their willes; ſo ſhould I, if I were one. I would
we were all of one minde, and one minde good: O there
were deſolation of Gaolers and Galowſes: I ſpeake a-
gainſt my preſent profit, but my wiſh hath a preferment
in’t.

scene.stagedir: Enter Cymbeline, Bellarius, Guiderius, Aruiragus, Piſanio, and Lords.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: Stand by my ſide you, whom the Gods haue made
Preſeruers of my Throne: wœ is my heart,
That the poore Souldier that ſo richly fought,
Whoſe ragges, ſham’d gilded Armes, whoſe naked breſt
Stept before Targes of proofe, cannot be found:
He ſhall be happy that can finde him, if
Our Grace can make him ſo.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: I neuer ſaw
Such Noble fury in ſo poore a Thing;
Such precious deeds, in one that promiſt nought
But beggery, and poore lookes.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: No tydings of him?

speech.speaker: Piſa.
speech.line: He hath bin ſearch’d among the dead, & liuing;
But no trace of him.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: To my greefe, I am
The heyre of his Reward, which I will adde
To you (the Liuer, Heart, and Braine of Britaine)
By whom (I grant) ſhe liues. ’Tis now the time
To aske of whence you are. Report it.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Sir,
In Cambria are we borne, and Gentlemen:
Further to boaſt, were neyther true, nor modeſt,
Vnleſſe I adde, we are honeſt.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: Bow your knees:
Ariſe my Knights o’th’Battell, I create you
Companions to our perſon, and will fit you
With Dignities becomming your eſtates.
There’s buſineſſe in theſe faces: why ſo ſadly
Greet you our Viƈtory? you looke like Romaines,
And not o’th’Court of Britaine.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Hayle great King,
To ſowre your happineſſe, I muſt report
The Queene is dead.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: Who worſe then a Phyſitian
Would this report become? But I conſider,
By Med’cine life may be prolong’d, yet death
Will ſeize the Doƈtor too. How ended ſhe?

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: With horror, madly dying, like her life,
Which (being cruell to the world) concluded
Moſt cruell to her ſelfe. What ſhe confeſt,
I will report, ſo pleaſe you. Theſe her Women
Can trip me, if I erre, who with wet cheekes
Were preſent when ſhe finiſh’d.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: Prythee ſay.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Firſt, ſhe confeſt ſhe neuer lou’d you: onely
Affeƈted Greatneſſe got by you: not you:
Married your Royalty, was wife to your place:
Abhorr’d your perſon.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: She alone knew this:
And but ſhe ſpoke it dying, I would not
Beleeue her lips in opening it. Proceed.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Your daughter, whom ſhe bore in hand to loue
With ſuch integrity, ſhe did confeſſe
Was as a Scorpion to her ſight, whoſe life
(But that her flight preuented it) ſhe had
Tane off by poyſon.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: O moſt delicate Fiend!
Who is’t can reade a Woman? Is there more?

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: More Sir, and worſe. She did confeſſe ſhe had
For you a mortall Minerall, which being tooke,
Should by the minute feede on life, and ling’ring,
By inches waſte you. In which time, ſhe purpos’d
By watching, weeping, tendance, kiſſing, to
Orecome you with her ſhew; and in time
(When ſhe had fitted you with her craft, to worke
Her Sonne into th’adoption of the Crowne:
But fayling of her end by his ſtrange abſence,
Grew ſhameleſſe deſperate, open’d (in deſpight
Of Heauen, and Men) her purpoſes: repented
The euils ſhe hatch’d, were not effeƈted: ſo
Diſpayring, dyed.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: Heard you all this, her Women?

speech.speaker: La.
speech.line: We did, ſo pleaſe your Highneſſe.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: Mine eyes
Were not in fault, for ſhe was beautifull:
Mine eares that heare her flattery, nor my heart,
That thought her like her ſeeming. It had beene vicious
To haue miſtruſted her: yet (Oh my Daughter)
That it was folly in me, thou mayſt ſay,
And proue it in thy feeling. Heauen mend all.
speech.stagedir: Enter Lucius, Iachimo, and other Roman priſoners, Leonatus behind, and Imogen.
speech.line: Thou comm’ſt not Caius now for Tribute, that
The Britaines haue rac’d out, though with the loſſe
Of many a bold one: whoſe Kinſmen haue made ſuite
That their good ſoules may be appeas’d, with ſlaughter
Of you their Captiues, which our ſelfe haue granted,
So thinke of your eſtate.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Conſider Sir, the chance of Warre, the day
Was yours by accident: had it gone with vs,
We ſhould not when the blood was cool, haue threatend
Our Priſoners with the Sword. But ſince the Gods
Will haue it thus, that nothing but our liues
May be call’d ranſome, let it come: Sufficeth,
A Roman, with a Romans heart can ſuffer:
Auguſtus liues to thinke on’t: and ſo much
For my peculiar care. This one thing onely
I will entreate, my Boy (a Britaine borne)
Let him be ranſom’d: Neuer Maſter had
A Page ſo kinde, ſo duteous, diligent,
So tender ouer his occaſions, true,
So feate, ſo Nurſe-like: let his vertue ioyne
With my requeſt, which Ile make bold your Highneſſe
Cannot deny: he hath done no Britaine harme,
Though he haue ſeru’d a Roman. Saue him (Sir)
And ſpare no blood beſide.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: I haue ſurely ſeene him:
His fauour is familiar to me: Boy,
Thou haſt look’d thy ſelfe into my grace,
And art mine owne. I know not why, wherefore,
To ſay, liue boy: ne’re thanke thy Maſter, liue;
And aske of Cymbeline what Boone thou wilt,
Fitting my bounty, and thy ſtate, Ile giue it:
Yea, though thou do demand a Priſoner
The Nobleſt tane.

speech.speaker: Imo.
speech.line: I humbly thanke your Highneſſe.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: I do not bid thee begge my life, good Lad,
And yet I know thou wilt.

speech.speaker: Imo.
speech.line: No, no, alacke,
There’s other worke in hand: I ſee a thing
Bitter to me, as death: your life, good Maſter,
Muſt ſhuffle for it ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: The Boy diſdaines me,
He leaues me, ſcornes me: briefely dye their ioyes,
That place them on the truth of Gyrles, and Boyes.
Why ſtands he ſo perplext?

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: What would’ſt thou Boy?
I loue thee more, and more: thinke more and more
What’s beſt to aske. Know’ſt him thou look’ſt on? ſpeak
Wilt haue him liue? Is he thy Kin? thy Friend?

speech.speaker: Imo.
speech.line: He is a Romane, no more kin to me,
Then I to your Highneſſe, who being born your vaſſaile
Am ſomething neerer.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: Wherefore ey’ſt him ſo?

speech.speaker: Imo.
speech.line: Ile tell you (Sir) in priuate, if you pleaſe
To giue me hearing.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: I, with all my heart,
And lend my beſt attention. What’s thy name?

speech.speaker: Imo.
speech.line: Fidele Sir.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: Thou’rt my good youth: my Page
Ile be thy Maſter: walke with me: ſpeake freely.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Is not this Boy reuiu’d from death?

speech.speaker: Arui.
speech.line: One Sand another
Not more reſembles that ſweet Roſie Lad:
Who dyed, and was Fidele: what thinke you?

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: The ſame dead thing aliue.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Peace, peace, ſee further: he eyes vs not, forbeare
Creatures may be alike: were’t he, I am ſure
He would haue ſpoke to vs.

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: But we ſee him dead.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Be ſilent: let’s ſee further.

speech.speaker: Piſa.
speech.line: It is my Miſtris:
Since ſhe is liuing, let the time run on,
To good, or bad.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: Come, ſtand thou by our ſide,
Make thy demand alowd. Sir, ſtep you forth,
Giue anſwer to this Boy, and do it freely,
Or by our Greatneſſe, and the grace of it
(Which is our Honor) bitter torture ſhall
Winnow the truth from falſhood. One ſpeake to him.

speech.speaker: Imo.
speech.line: My boone is, that this Gentleman may render
Of whom he had this Ring.

speech.speaker: Poſt.
speech.line: What’s that to him?

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: That Diamond vpon your Finger, ſay
How came it yours?

speech.speaker: Iach.
speech.line: Thou’lt torture me to leaue vnſpoken, that
Which to be ſpoke, wou’d torture thee.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: How? me?

speech.speaker: Iach.
speech.line: I am glad to be conſtrain’d to vtter that
Which torments me to conceale. By Villany
I got this Ring: ’twas Leonatus Iewell,
Whom thou did’ſt baniſh: and which more may greeue thee,
As it doth me: a Nobler Sir, ne’re liu’d
’Twixt ſky and ground. Wilt thou heare more my Lord?

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: All that belongs to this.

speech.speaker: Iach.
speech.line: That Paragon, thy daughter,
For whom my heart drops blood, and my falſe ſpirits
Quaile to remember. Giue me leaue, I faint.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: My Daughter? what of hir? Renew thy ſtrength
I had rather thou ſhould’ſt liue, while Nature will,
Then dye ere I heare more: ſtriue man, and ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Iach.
speech.line: Vpon a time, vnhappy was the clocke
That ſtrooke the houre: it was in Rome, accurſt
The Manſion where: ’twas at a Feaſt, oh would
Our Viands had bin poyſon’d (or at leaſt
Thoſe which I heau’d to head:) the good Poſthumus,
(What ſhould I ſay? he was too good to be
Where ill men were, and was the beſt of all
Among’ſt the rar’ſt of good ones) ſitting ſadly,
Hearing vs praiſe our Loues of Italy
For Beauty, that made barren the ſwell’d boaſt
Of him that beſt could ſpeake: for Feature, laming
The Shrine of Venus, or ſtraight-pight Minerua,
Poſtures, beyond breefe Nature. For Condition,
A ſhop of all the qualities, that man
Loues woman for, besides that hooke of Wiuing,
Faireneſſe, which ſtrikes the eye.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: I ſtand on fire. Come to the matter.

speech.speaker: Iach.
speech.line: All too ſoone I ſhall,
Vnleſſe thou would’ſt greeue quickly. This Poſthumus,
Moſt like a Noble Lord, in loue, and one
That had a Royall Louer, tooke his hint,
And (not diſpraiſing whom we prais’d, therein
He was as calme as vertue) he began
His Miſtris piƈture, which, by his tongue, being made,
And then a minde put in’t, either our bragges
Were crak’d of Kitchin-Trulles, or his deſcription
Prou’d vs vnſpeaking ſottes.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: Nay, nay, to’th’purpoſe.

speech.speaker: Iach.
speech.line: Your daughters Chaſtity, (there it beginnes)
He ſpake of her, as Dian had hot dreames,
And ſhe alone, were cold: Whereat, I wretch
Made ſcruple of his praiſe, and wager’d with him
Peeces of Gold, ’gainſt this, which then he wore
Vpon his honour’d finger) to attaine
In ſuite the place of’s bed, and winne this Ring
By hers, and mine Adultery: he (true Knight)
No leſſer of her Honour confident
Then I did truly finde her, ſtakes this Ring,
And would ſo, had it beene a Carbuncle
Of Phœbus Wheele; and might ſo ſafely, had it
Bin all the worth of’s Carre. Away to Britaine
Poſte I in this designe: Well may you (Sir)
Remember me at Court, where I was taught
Of your chaſte Daughter, the wide difference
’Twixt Amorous, and Villanous. Being thus quench’d
