Of hope, not longing; mine Italian braine,
Gan in your duller Britaine operate
Moſt vildely: for my vantage excellent.
And to be breefe, my praƈtiſe ſo preuayl’d
That I return’d with ſimular proofe enough,
To make the Noble Leonatus mad,
By wounding his beleefe in her Renowne,
With Tokens thus, and thus: auerring notes
Of Chamber-hanging, Piƈtures, this her Bracelet
(Oh cunning how I got) nay ſome markes
Of ſecret on her perſon, that he could not
But thinke her bond of Chaſtity quite crack’d,
I hauing ’tane the forfeyt. Whereupon,
Me thinkes I ſee him now.

speech.speaker: Poſt.
speech.line: I ſo thou do’ſt,
Italian Fiend. Aye me, moſt credulous Foole,
Egregious murtherer, Theefe, any thing
That’s due to all the Villaines paſt, in being
To come. Oh giue me Cord, or knife, or poyſon,
Some vpright Iuſticer. Thou King, ſend out
For Torturors ingenious: it is I
That all th’abhorred things o’th’earth amend
By being worſe then they. I am Poſthumus,
That kill’d thy Daughter: Villain-like, I lye,
That caus’d a leſſer villaine then my ſelfe,
A ſacrilegious Theefe to doo’t. The Temple
Of Vertue was ſhe; yea, and ſhe her ſelfe.
Spit, and throw ſtones, caſt myre vpon me, ſet
The dogges o’th’ſtreet to bay me: euery villaine
Be call’d Poſthumus Leonatus, and
Be villany leſſe then ’twas. Oh Imogen!
My Queene, my life, my wife: oh Imogen,
Imogen, Imogen.

speech.speaker: Imo.
speech.line: Peace my Lord, heare, heare.

speech.speaker: Poſt.
speech.line: Shall’s haue a play of this?
Thou ſcornfull Page, there lye thy part.

speech.speaker: Piſ.
speech.line: Oh Gentlemen, helpe,
Mine and your Miſtris: Oh my Lord Poſthumus,
You ne’re kill’d Imogen till now: helpe, helpe,
Mine honour’d Lady.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: Dœs the world go round?

speech.speaker: Poſth.
speech.line: How comes theſe ſtaggers on mee?

speech.speaker: Pisa.
speech.line: Wake my Miſtris.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: If this be ſo, the Gods do meane to ſtrike me
To death, with mortall ioy.

speech.speaker: Piſa.
speech.line: How fares my Miſtris?

speech.speaker: Imo.
speech.line: Oh get thee from my ſight,
Thou gau’ſt me poyſon: dangerous Fellow hence,
Breath not where Princes are.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: The tune of Imogen.

speech.speaker: Piſa.
speech.line: Lady, the Gods throw ſtones of ſulpher on me, if
That box I gaue you, was not thought by mee
A precious thing, I had it from the Queene.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: New matter ſtill.

speech.speaker: Imo.
speech.line: It poyſon’d me.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Oh Gods!
I left out one thing which the Queene confeſt,
Which muſt approue thee honeſt. If Paſanio
Haue (said ſhe) giuen his Miſtris that Confeƈtion
Which I gaue him for Cordiall, ſhe is ſeru’d,
As I would ſerue a Rat.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: What’s this, Cornelius?

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: The Queene (Sir) very oft importun’d me
To temper poyſons for her, ſtill pretending
The ſatisfaƈtion of her knowledge, onely
In killing Creatures vilde, as Cats and Dogges
Of no eſteeme. I dreading, that her purpoſe
Was of more danger, did compound for her
A certaine ſtuffe, which being tane, would ceaſe
The preſent powre of life, but in ſhort time,
All Offices of Nature, ſhould againe
Do their due Funƈtions. Haue you tane of it?

speech.speaker: Imo.
speech.line: Moſt like I did, for I was dead.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: My Boyes, there was our error.

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: This is ſure Fidele.

speech.speaker: Imo.
speech.line: Why did you throw your wedded Lady fro you?
Thinke that you are vpon a Rocke, and now
Throw me againe.

speech.speaker: Poſt.
speech.line: Hang there like fruite, my ſoule,
Till the Tree dye.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: How now, my Fleſh? my Childe?
What, mak’ſt thou me a dullard in this Aƈt?
Wilt thou not ſpeake to me?

speech.speaker: Imo.
speech.line: Your bleſſing, Sir.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Though you did loue this youth, I blame ye not,
You had a motiue for’t.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: My teares that fall
Proue holy-water on thee; Imogen,
Thy Mothers dead.

speech.speaker: Imo.
speech.line: I am ſorry for’t, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: Oh, ſhe was naught; and long of her it was
That we meet heere ſo ſtrangely: but her Sonne
Is gone, we know not how, nor where.

speech.speaker: Piſa.
speech.line: My Lord,
Now feare is from me, Ile ſpeake troth. Lord Cloten
Vpon my Ladies miſſing, came to me
With his Sword drawne, foam’d at the mouth, and ſwore
If I diſcouer’d not which way ſhe was gone,
It was my inſtant death. By accident,
I had a feigned Letter of my Maſters
Then in my pocket, which direƈted him
To ſeeke her on the Mountaines neere to Milford,
Where in a frenzie, in my Maſters Garments
(Which he inforc’d from me) away he Poſtes
With vnchaſte purpoſe, and with oath to violate
My Ladies honor, what became of him,
I further know not.

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: Let me end the Story: I ſlew him there.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: Marry, the Gods forefend.
I would not thy good deeds, ſhould from my lips
Plucke a hard ſentence: Prythee valiant youth
Deny’t againe.

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: I haue ſpoke it, and I did it.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: He was a Prince.

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: A moſt inciuill one. The wrongs he did mee
Were nothing Prince-like; for he did prouoke me
With Language that would make me ſpurne the Sea,
If it could ſo roare to me. I cut off’s head,
And am right glad he is not ſtanding heere
To tell this tale of mine.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: I am ſorrow for thee:
By thine owne tongue thou art condemn’d, and muſt
Endure our Law: Thou’rt dead.

speech.speaker: Imo.
speech.line: That headleſſe man I thought had bin my Lord

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: Binde the Offender,
And take him from our preſence.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Stay, Sir King.
This man is better then the man he ſlew,
As well deſcended as thy ſelfe, and hath
More of thee merited, then a Band of Clotens
Had euer ſcarre for. Let his Armes alone,
They were not borne for bondage.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: Why old Soldier:
Wilt thou vndoo the worth thou art vnpayd for
By taſting of our wrath? How of deſcent
As good as we?

speech.speaker: Arui.
speech.line: In that he ſpake too farre.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: And thou ſhalt dye for’t.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: We will dye all three,
But I will proue that two one’s are as good
As I haue giuen out him. My Sonnes, I muſt
For mine owne part, vnfold a dangerous ſpeech,
Though haply well for you.

speech.speaker: Arui.
speech.line: Your danger’s ours.

speech.speaker: Guid.
speech.line: And our good his.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Haue at it then, by leaue
Thou hadd’ſt (great King) a Subieƈt, who
Was call’d Belarius.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: What of him? He is a baniſh’d Traitor.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: He it is, that hath
Aſſum’d this age: indeed a baniſh’d man,
I know not how, a Traitor.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: Take him hence,
The whole world ſhall not ſaue him.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Not too hot;
Firſt pay me for the Nurſing of thy Sonnes,
And let it be confiſcate all, ſo ſoone
As I haue receyu’d it.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: Nurſing of my Sonnes?

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: I am too blunt, and ſawcy: heere’s my knee:
Ere I ariſe, I will preferre my Sonnes,
Then ſpare not the old Father. Mighty Sir,
Theſe two young Gentlemen that call me Father,
And thinke they are my Sonnes, are none of mine,
They are the yſſue of your Loynes, my Liege,
And blood of your begetting.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: How? my Iſſue.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: So ſure as you, your Fathers: I (old Morgan)
Am that Belarius, whom you ſometime baniſh’d:
Your pleaſure was my neere offence, my puniſhment
It ſelfe, and all my Treaſon that I ſuffer’d,
Was all the harme I did. Theſe gentle Princes
(For ſuch, and ſo they are) theſe twenty yeares
Haue I train’d vp; thoſe Arts they haue, as I
Could put into them. My breeding was (Sir)
As your Highneſſe knowes: Their Nurſe Euriphile
(Whom for the Theft I wedded) ſtole theſe Children
Vpon my Baniſhment: I moou’d her too’t,
Hauing receyu’d the puniſhment before
For that which I did then. Beaten for Loyaltie,
Excited me to Treaſon. Their deere loſſe,
The more of you ’twas felt, the more it ſhap’d
Vnto my end of ſtealing them. But gracious Sir,
Heere are your Sonnes againe, and I muſt looſe
Two of the ſweet’ſt Companions in the World.
The benediƈtion of theſe couering Heauens
Fall on their heads like dew, for they are worthie
To in-lay Heauen with Starres.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: Thou weep’ſt, and ſpeak’ſt:
The Seruice that you three haue done, is more
Vnlike, then this thou tell’ſt. I loſt my Children,
If theſe be they, I know not how to wiſh
A payre of worthier Sonnes.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: Be pleas’d awhile;
This Gentleman, whom I call Polidore,
Moſt worthy Prince, as yours, is true Guiderius:
This Gentleman, my Cadwall, Aruiragus.
Your yonger Princely Son, he Sir, was lapt
In a moſt curious Mantle, wrought by th’hand
Of his Queene Mother, which for more probation
I can with eaſe produce.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: Guiderius had
Vpon his necke a Mole, a ſanguine Starre,
It was a marke of wonder.

speech.speaker: Bel.
speech.line: This is he,
Who hath vpon him ſtill that naturall ſtampe:
It was wiſe Natures end, in the donation
To be his euidence now.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: Oh, what am I
A Mother to the byrth of three? Nere Mother
Reioyc’d deliuerance more: Bleſt, pray you be,
That after this ſtrange ſtarting from your Orbes,
You may reigne in them now: Oh Imogen,
Thou haſt loſt by this a Kingdome.

speech.speaker: Imo.
speech.line: No, my Lord:
I haue got two Worlds by’t. Oh my gentle Brothers,
Haue we thus met? Oh neuer ſay heereafter
But I am trueſt ſpeaker. You call’d me Brother
When I was but your Siſter: I you Brothers,
When we were ſo indeed.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: Did you ere meete?

speech.speaker: Arui.
speech.line: I my good Lord.

speech.speaker: Gui.
speech.line: And at firſt meeting lou’d,
Continew’d ſo, vntill we thought he dyed.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: By the Queenes Dramme ſhe ſwallow’d.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: O rare inſtinƈt!
When ſhall I heare all through? This fierce abridgment,
Hath to it Circumſtantiall branches, which
Diſtinƈtion ſhould be rich in. Where? how liu’d you?
And when came you to ſerue our Romane Captiue?
How parted with your Brother? How firſt met them?
Why fled you from the Court? And whether theſe?
And your three motiues to the Battaile? with
I know not how much more ſhould be demanded,
And all the other by-dependances
From chance to chance? But nor the Time, nor Place
Will ſerue our long Interrogatories. See,
Poſthumus Anchors vpon Imogen;
And ſhe (like harmleſſe Lightning) throwes her eye
On him: her Brothers, Me: her Maſter hitting
Each obieƈt with a Ioy: the Counter-change
Is ſeuerally in all. Let’s quit this ground,
And ſmoake the Temple with our Sacrifices.
Thou art my Brother, ſo wee’l hold thee euer.

speech.speaker: Imo.
speech.line: You are my Father too, and did releeue me:
To ſee this gracious ſeaſon.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: All ore-ioy’d
Saue theſe in bonds, let them be ioyfull too,
For they ſhall taſte our Comfort.

speech.speaker: Imo.
speech.line: My good Maſter, I will yet do you ſeruice.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Happy be you.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: The forlorne Souldier, that ſo Nobly fought
He would haue well becom’d this place, and grac’d
The thankings of a King.

speech.speaker: Poſt.
speech.line: I am Sir
The Souldier that did company theſe three
In poore beſeeming: ’twas a fitment for
The purpoſe I then follow’d. That I was he,
Speake Iachimo, I had you downe, and might
Haue made you finiſh.

speech.speaker: Iach.
speech.line: I am downe againe:
But now my heauie Conſcience ſinkes my knee,
As then your force did. Take that life, beſeech you
Which I ſo often owe: but your Ring firſt,
And heere the Bracelet of the trueſt Princeſſe
That euer ſwore the Faith.

speech.speaker: Poſt.
speech.line: Kneele not to me:
The powre that I haue on you, is to ſpare you:
The malice towards you, to forgiue you. Liue
And deale with others better.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: Nobly doom’d:
Wee’l learne our Freeneſſe of a Sonne-in-Law:
Pardon’s the word to all.

speech.speaker: Arui.
speech.line: You holpe vs Sir,
As you did meane indeed to be our Brother,
Ioy’d are we, that you are.

speech.speaker: Poſt.
speech.line: Your Seruant Princes. Good my Lord of Rome
Call forth your Sooth-sayer: As I ſlept, me thought
Great Iupiter vpon his Eagle back’d
Appear’d to me, with other ſprightly ſhewes
Of mine owne Kindred. When I wak’d, I found
This Labell on my boſome; whoſe containing
Is ſo from ſenſe in hardneſſe, that I can
Make no Colleƈtion of it. Let him ſhew
His ſkill in the conſtruƈtion.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Philarmonus.

speech.speaker: Sooth.
speech.line: Heere, my good Lord.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Read, and declare the meaning.

line.italic: When as a Lyons whelpe, ſhall to himſelfe vnknown, with-
out ſeeking finde, and bee embrac’d by a peece of tender
Ayre: And when from a ſtately Cedar ſhall be lopt branches,
which being dead many yeares, ſhall after reuiue, bee ioynted to
the old Stocke, and freſhly grow, then ſhall Poſthumus end his
miſeries, Britaine be fortunate, and flouriſh in Peace and Plen-
tie.

speech.line: Thou Leonatus art the Lyons Whelpe,
The fit and apt Conſtruƈtion of thy name
Being Leonatus, doth import ſo much:
The peece of tender Ayre, thy vertuous Daughter,
Which we call Mollis Aer, and Mollis Aer
We terme it Mulier; which Mulier I diuine
Is this moſt conſtant Wife, who euen now
Anſwering the Letter of the Oracle,
Vnknowne to you vnſought, were clipt about
With this moſt tender Aire.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: This hath ſome ſeeming.

speech.speaker: Sooth.
speech.line: The lofty Cedar, Royall Cymbeline
Perſonates thee: And thy lopt Branches, point
Thy two Sonnes forth: who by Belarius ſtolne
For many yeares thought dead, are now reuiu’d
To the Maieſticke Cedar ioyn’d; whoſe Iſſue
Promiſes Britaine, Peace and Plenty.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: Well,
My Peace we will begin: And Caius Lucius,
Although the Viƈtor, we ſubmit to Cæſar,
And to the Romane Empire; promiſing
To pay our wonted Tribute, from the which
We were diſſwaded by our wicked Queene,
Whom heauens in Iuſtice both on her, and hers,
Haue laid moſt heauy hand.

speech.speaker: Sooth.
speech.line: The fingers of the Powres aboue, do tune
The harmony of this Peace: the Viſion
Which I made knowne to Lucius ere the ſtroke
Of yet this ſcarſe-cold-Battaile, at this inſtant
Is full accompliſh’d. For the Romaine Eagle
From South to Weſt, on wing ſoaring aloft
Leſſen’d her ſelfe, and in the Beames o’th’Sun
So vaniſh’d; which fore-shew’d our Princely Eagle
Th’Imperiall Cæſar, ſhould againe vnite
His Fauour, with the Radiant Cymbeline,
Which ſhines heere in the Weſt.

speech.speaker: Cym.
speech.line: Laud we the Gods,
And let our crooked Smoakes climbe to their Noſtrils
From our bleſt Altars. Publiſh we this Peace
To all our Subieƈts. Set we forward: Let
A Roman, and a Brittiſh Enſigne waue
Friendly together: ſo through Luds-Towne march,
And in the Temple of great Iupiter
Our Peace wee’l ratifie: Seale it with Feaſts.
Set on there: Neuer was a Warre did ceaſe
(Ere bloodie hands were waſh’d) with ſuch a Peace.
